text: In Predictably Irrational: The Hidden Forces That Shape Our Decisions, Dan Ariely examines how framing affects consumer choices. He describes an experiment where participants were offered three subscription options for a magazine: digital-only, print-only, and a bundled print-and-digital option priced the same as the print-only subscription. Most participants chose the bundled option, perceiving it as the best value. Ariely explains that the presence of the seemingly inferior print-only option made the bundled offer appear more attractive. He argues that understanding how options are presented can reveal how people make decisions. This finding suggests that ______.
question: Which choice most logically completes the text?
A: consumers are unlikely to consider pricing when choosing between subscription options.
B: consumers typically choose the cheapest option when presented with multiple choices.
C: bundled offers are always more appealing to consumers than single-product options.
D: the way choices are framed can significantly influence consumer decision-making.
explanation:
Choice B is the best answer. Ariely demonstrates how framing affects perceptions of value, influencing participants to select the bundled option.Choice A is incorrect. The text highlights how participants’ decisions were influenced by pricing and perceived value, not that pricing was ignored.Choice C is incorrect. While the bundled option was appealing in this scenario, the text does not generalize this as true for all situations.Choice D is incorrect. The participants did not choose the cheapest option but rather the one they perceived as offering the best value.
